newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia shocked by mercy killing first.
newsitem.headline: Australia shocked by mercy killing first.

text.p: An elderly cancer patient has become the first person to take his life under Australia's unique voluntary euthanasia law, the doctor who assisted his suicide said on Thursday.

The man, named by local media as Bob Dent, died by a computer-delivered lethal injection in this northern outback city on Sunday after persuading doctors that his case was hopeless and he knew what he was doing.
In an emotional open letter written on the eve of his death, Dent said painkilling drugs given for his prostate cancer made him suicidal.
"If I were to keep a pet animal in the same condition I am in, I would be prosecuted," he wrote.
News of Dent's death outraged political and religious leaders, many of whom are campaigning to have the law quashed in either the federal parliament or High Court.

"I was, and still am, deeply ashamed that Australia should be the only country in the world to legalise the killing of an innocent person," Roman Catholic archbishop Edward Clancy told a news conference outside the city's St Mary's Cathedral.
"Respect, reverence for human life is a cornerstone of our civilisation," Clancy added. "When that goes, our society begins to unravel."

Darwin doctor Philip Nitschke told Reuters he had helped his dying patient administer a lethal injection on Sunday. It was the first time that the Northern Territory's euthanasia law had been successfully used since it came into operation on July 1.
Dent wrote that "drugs given to enhance the pain-relieving effects of the morphine have caused me to feel suicidal to the point that I would have blown my head off if I had had a gun.
"I have always been an active, outgoing person, and being unable to live a normal life causes much mental and psychological pain, which can never be relieved by medication."
Nitschke told reporters the atmosphere at Dent's Darwin home, where the euthanasia was carried out, had at first been tense and disquieting.
But Dent had reassured him and told him it was an act of love. "The patient was expressing a sense of gratitude. He was as happy as someone could be under the circumstances," Nitschke said.
The deputy prime minister in Australia's conservative government, Tim Fischer, repeated warnings the territory law was a move towards "a culture of death".
Prime Minister John Howard, Labor opposition leader Kim Beazley and other prominent community leaders have also condemned the territory law.
The law has also been condemned by Australia's indigenous Aborigines.
Since it came into operation, the law has been hit by a series of political and legal challenges which had until this month deterred doctors from approving patients' deaths.
Government backbencher Kevin Andrews, backed by Howard, has launched a private action in parliament that would see the national parliament use its constitutional powers to quash the territory law.
But Dent, in his letter, urged parliament to allow people to choose to die when the bill is voted on later this year.

"The church and state should be kept separate," he wrote. "What right has anyone because of their own religious faith, to which I don't subscribe, to demand that I behave according to their rules and endure unnecessary intractable pain.
"If you disagree with voluntary euthanasia, then don't use it, but please don't deny the right to me to use it."
Andrews told reporters he was protecting the community and warned the law could be abused.

"It's not just an issue that affects one individual, or even that individual and his or her families, it's a matter which effects the entire community.... the way in which we see things such as death and care and what hope we give people," he said.
Andrews' challenge is the latest in a series of legal and political attacks on the territory law.
Challenges in the territory parliament and the territory's Supreme Court have failed.

The law faces a separate threat in Australia's highest court, the High Court, where an anti-euthanasia coalition of doctors, church and Aboriginal leaders is seeking to have it declared unconstitutional.
